questions.text: What is the number of eligible couples per 1000 population in India?
questions.solution:
There are approximately 150 – 180 eligible couples per 1000 population in India.

An eligible couple refers to a currently married couple wherein the wife belongs to the reproductive age group (15-49 years of age).

questions.text: Scope of modern concept of family planning services include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Screening for HIV infection does not come under the purview of family planning.

The modern concepts of family planning services include:

  • Proper spacing and limitation of birth
  • Advice on sterility
  • Education for parenthood
  • Sex education
  • Screening for pathological conditions related to the reproductive system (e.g. cervical cancer)
  • Genetic counseling
  • Premarital consultation and examination
  • Pregnancy tests
  • Marriage counseling
  • Preparation of couples for the first child
  • Providing services to unmarried mothers
  • Teaching home economics and nutrition
  • Providing adoption services

questions.text:
A study was conducted in a village with 180 eligible couples, to gather data on the different contraceptive methods used. The data obtained are given below. What is the couple protection rate in the village?

Vasectomy – 15

Tubectomy – 15

Intrauterine device (IUD) users – 8

Oral pill users – 15

Condom users – 7
questions.solution:
Couple protection rate (CPR) is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning. 

In the given scenario, 60 out of 180 eligible couples are using different contraceptive methods. Therefore, CPR = (60/180) x 100 = 33%.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Which of the following  is not a barrier method of contraception?
questions.solution:
Lippes loop is an intrauterine device and not a barrier method of contraception. 

Barrier methods of contraception include:

  • Physical methods – male and female condoms, diaphragm, vaginal sponge (Today)
  • Chemical methods – foam tablets, aerosols, creams, jellies, suppositories, and soluble films (C-films)

questions.text: A sexually active woman has been using Today sponge as a contraceptive. What does this contain?
questions.solution:
Today is a type of vaginal sponge that contains 9 – nonoxynol.

Today is a barrier contraceptive inserted vaginally. It has to be left in place for 6 hours after coitus. It can lead to toxic shock syndrome if left in place for more than 24 hours (rarely).

questions.text:
Which of the following is a second-generation intra-uterine device?
  1. Lippes loop
  2. Mirena
  3. Nova T
  4. Progestasert
  5. Cu-T-380 Ag
questions.solution:
Nova T and Cu-T-380 Ag are second-generation intrauterine devices (IUD). 

IUD is a contraceptive method inserted into the uterine cavity. The different generations of IUDs include:

  • First-generation IUDs – inert or non-medicated devices like Lippes loop
  • Second-generation IUDs - medicated with metallic elements like copper eg: Cu-T-220 C, Nova T, Multi-load Cu-250, Multi-load Cu-375
  • Third-generation IUDs – hormone-containing IUDs like progestasert, Mirena (LNG-20)

questions.text: Which of the following women will not be considered ideal candidates for IUD insertion?

choices.text: A woman in a monogamous relationship
A woman with no access to follow up
A woman who has at least one living child

questions.solution:
A woman with no access to follow-up is not considered an ideal candidate for IUD insertion. 

An ideal candidate for an IUD must have the following attributes:

  • Has at least one child
  • No history of pelvic disease
  • Normal menstrual periods
  • Must be willing to check IUD tail
  • Has access to follow up and for treatment of potential problems
  • Is in a monogamous relationship

questions.text: A patient who underwent an IUD insertion is most likely to develop which of the following in the future?
questions.solution:
Patients who underwent IUD insertion are most likely to develop vaginal bleeding in the future.

Side effects and complications of IUDs include:

  • Vaginal bleeding – most common
  • Abdominal pain – second most common
  • Pelvic infection
  • Uterine perforation
  • Pregnancy - due to failure of contraception
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Expulsion of the IUD
  • Cancer and teratogenicity

questions.text:
Insertion of an IUD is not contraindicated in patients with which of the following conditions?
  1. PID
  2. Cardiac problems
  3. Carcinoma cervix
  4. Anemia
  5. Uterine fibroids
questions.solution:
Cardiac problems are not a contraindication for IUD usage.

Contraindications for IUD usage include:

Absolute contraindications

Relative contraindications
  • Suspected pregnancy
  • PID
  • Vaginal bleeding of unknown etiology
  • Carcinoma cervix /uterus/adnexa /other pelvic tumors
  • Anemia
  • Menorrhagia
  • History of PID since the last pregnancy
  • Purulent cervical discharge
  • Distortions of the uterine cavity due to fibroids
  • Uterine malformations
  • An unmotivated person

questions.text: Which of the following has the longest period of use?
questions.solution:
Cu-T-380 A has the longest period of use (10 years). 

IUD Years of use
Progestasert 1
Cu-T-200 4
Nova T 5
LNG IUD 7-10
Cu-T-380 A 10

questions.text: You have prescribed an IUCD to a multiparous woman. Which of the following is not a mechanism of action for this type of contraceptive?
questions.solution:
Prevention of ovulation is not a mechanism of action of IUCDs.

Mechanisms of action of IUCDs include:

  • Causing cellular and biochemical changes in the uterus and endometrium.
  • Prevention of sperm penetration due to changes in cervical mucus consistency.
  • Prevention of implantation by making the uterus hostile to it.

questions.text: All of the following are non-contraceptive benefits of oral contraceptive pills except?
questions.solution:
Oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) do not confer protection against thyroid dysfunction.

OCP usage can confer protection against:

  • Benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma and fibrocystic disease
  • Ovarian cysts
  • Iron-deficiency anemia
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Ovarian cancer

questions.text: In patients with which of the following conditions can OCPs be safely prescribed?
questions.solution:
Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) is not a contraindication for prescribing OCPs.

Absolute contraindications of OCPs: (CULT)

  • Cancers - breast and genital
  • Cardiac abnormalities
  • Congenital hyperlipidemia
  • Undiagnosed AUB
  • Liver disease
  • Thromboembolism - past or present history.

Medical surveillance is required while prescribing OCPs if the patient is/or has:

  • Age more than 40 years
  • Chronic smoker and age over 35 years
  • Amenorrhea
  • Chronic renal disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Epilepsy
  • In the first 6 months of nursing
  • Gall bladder disease
  • History of infrequent bleeding
  • Mild hypertension
  • Migraine

questions.text: A sexually active woman who was using barrier contraceptives is planning on switching to DMPA injectables. Which of the following is the correct dosage of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
The dosage for injectable depot-medroxyprogesterone acetate (DMPA) is 150 mg every 3 months.

It acts by:

  • Bringing changes in the cervical mucus
  • Making the endometrium hostile
  • Preventing ovulation

Disadvantages include spotting and intermediate per vaginal bleeding.

Antara (Injectable contraceptive DMPA) and Chhaya (oral contraceptive Centchroman) were launched by the Government under its Mission Parivar Vikas.

questions.text: Which of the following is also known as the Billings method of contraception?
questions.solution:
Billings method of contraception is also known as the cervical mucus method (or ovulation method). 

It is a natural method of contraception. It is based on the observation of changes in the cervical mucus. At ovulation, the mucus is watery clear, smooth, slippery and profuse. After ovulation, it becomes thicker and scarce.

The pattern of cervical mucus secretion during a menstrual cycle is given below:

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective natural method of contraception?
questions.solution:
The most effective natural method of contraception is the symptothermic method.

It combines:

  • Calendar method
  • Cervical mucus method
  • Basal body method.

In this method, if a woman is not able to identify one sign, she can double-check with her interpretation of the other signs.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a condition to be fulfilled by a male patient undergoing sterilization?

choices.text: Has at least one living child
Age should be more than 60 years

questions.solution:
A man should be below 60 years of age to be eligible for sterilization.

Eligibility for male sterilization:

  • Clients should be at least 22 years old
  • Clients should be below the age of 60 years
  • Clients should be married
  • The couple should have at least one child, whose age is above one year unless the sterilization is medically indicated
  • Clients or their spouses must not have undergone sterilization in the past (not applicable in the cases of failure of previous sterilization)
  • Clients must be in a sound state of mind, so as to understand the full implications of sterilization
  • Mentally ill clients must be certified by a psychiatrist, and a statement should be given by the legal guardian/spouse regarding the soundness of the client's state of mind

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of failure of vasectomy?
questions.solution:
The most common cause of failure of vasectomy is the mistaken identification of the vas.

This can be avoided by examining a stained smear prepared by squeezing the vas on a glass slide. If facilities are available a histological examination is preferred.

Causes of failure of vasectomy include: 

  • Mistaken identification of the vas - most common
  • Spontaneous recanalization of the vas
  • Presence of more than one vas on one side
  • Sexual intercourse before the disappearance of sperms from the reproductive tracts

questions.text: Which of the following is important in the calculation of the pearl index?

choices.text: Total number of women in the population

questions.solution:
The numerator used for calculation of the pearl index is total accidental pregnancies.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: As part of the National family planning program, you are conducting a study in a village to gather data on the efficacy of a new contraceptive. 20 out of 100 women became pregnant in the village despite using this contraceptive for a period of 2 years continuously. What is the pearl index of this contraceptive?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 10 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 20. The total months of exposure are 24 months for each woman.

Hence, the total months of exposure for 100 women are 24 x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/ Total months of exposure 

Hence, pearl index= 20 x 1200/2400 = 10 per HWY

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

questions.text: Out of 100 women who took oral contraceptive pills for contraception, 10 women got pregnant within 24 months. What is the Pearl index?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pearl index is 5 per HWY.

Here, the total number of accidental pregnancies is 10. There are 100 couples who are exposed to the method.

So, the total months of exposure are 24 months x 100 = 2400.

Pearl index = Total accidental pregnancies x 1200/Total months of exposure

Hence, pearl index = 10 x 1200/2400 = 5 per HWY. 

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.
